The following day,
Sunday, April 30th, we made Karachi, with an
Intermediata stop at Hasire Islard-another of those British strong pointe
which the Empire is built.
Then on to New Delhi where Bond was waiting
to greet us.
in New Delhi, calling on George Merrill,
Generals and
May 3rd we flew the last lap New Delhi to Calcutta, via Agra.
the latter point we circled the Taj Mahal at lon altitude.
Most of the
famous places I have seen leave ne
with a feeling of disappointment--due
perhaps to over-selling--but 1 had no such thought with respect so the Taj-
only great admiration for a thing which is perfection.
Caloutta--second city of the British Enyire-seething nillions,
stupid jry-e)kers who nake driving a constant strain--canels, bullock
carts, water buffaloss ploddiog along as in China and the Philipuines, pul-
Ling every type of casgo.
Stayed with the Sharp's (be is Operations Manager
Of GNAC with headquarters at the Compeny's main base at Dun Dun Airport) in
a modern apartment
building with seteral rooms air conditioned,
sharp's old Chinese boy from Hankow mas ou tag-delighted to see me
aad quiet to spoil me completely-pressed my clothes, drew uy baths, woke
ma with a glass of orange juice in one hand und morning paper in the other.
Upon my arival in Calcutta I found various neusuges of welcome
to coin me afteror le oaklay, sad loned that the linister of Com-
was away for tea doys.
had lots to do in Caloutte and so de-
cided to finiah up there before going on to Chungking.
The militery situa-
tion in the Kohina and Inpal sector- which looked pretty grim when I left
the J. S,--had improved subatentially, and latest reporta from General
Stillwell indicated tbat there as no longer any real danger thatthe Jape
would be able to out the railroad line serving the raithead fron which Nac
starts its imbensive operations over the "hung".
Bond and I ayent the nent few days calling on various Army
and Chinese and Amarican offielals.
I took a Sunday off to play golf with
shar, at the Royal Calcutta Golf Club dinned at the very stuffy Bengal Club
where one requirement for mombership is 15 years residence in India.
the 10th there was an air raid alarm which I slept completely through in my
air-conditioned room.
Saturday the 23th Bond and I flew up to Dinjan-INAC base 1a
northern Assau.
Te passed within 40 miles of Imphal and closer to Rohina,
It was hard to realize that a desperate struggle between inglish and Japanese
forces was actually going on at that very moment over there where the green
jungle not the blue horizon. At Dinjen we inspected the CNAC base and spent
the night with the Woods--CNAC Freigat Manager who runs the hump operation.
He and Hrs. Woods board with an old Scotch doctor uno acts as medico for a
group of tea plantations which dot the countryside.
The tea planters have done extreordinarily well with the result
that the whole countryside has a park-like look of well-being. The spacious
plantation menagers are surrounded by lovely gardens full of flower-
ing plants and high climbing bougainville.
Hedgerows are neat and trin,
giving en air of prosperity to the mole countryside, with its thousands of
acres of tea bushes neatly planted row on row as fur as the eye can see.
